But John Turturro, who wrote and directed ""Fading Gigolo"" in addition to starring in it, has conceived the promised menage a trois as a kind of delirious anticlimax, one he builds to with more nuanced stories about Murray's domestic situation with an African-American mom and four kids, about a Jewish neighborhood watch group that works with Brooklyn police and rabbinical courts and about a Hasidic widow, who brings all these threads together and becomes the innocent heart of ""Fading Gigolo"" when Murray introduces her to Fioravante, not for sex, but because widowhood has pulled her so utterly away from the world.

Woody Allen reportedly had a hand in helping Turturro refine the script, and together, they've succeeded in keeping the mood light even as the filmmaker is gently tugging the plot in other directions, to look at loneliness and longing and heartbreak, things that, if you think about it, are just what you'd expect to find in a film about a gigolo, though, perhaps not a film with as much charm and sweetness as ""Fading Gigolo."" Dean is south of Hispaniola and is expected to dump as much as five inches of rain overnight on Haiti and the Dominican Republic, both nations prone to floods and mudslides.

I spoke earlier with Cecil Bailey, the deputy director general for Jamaica's Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management.
I asked him what preparations were underway?

Well, what we are doing currently is that we have activated the National Emergency Operation Center, and we are coordinating pre-positioning of supplies with the national agencies that have various responsibilities as related to response in the aftermath.
We are in the process of organizing our shelters and opening some.
And we're - we are also going to be issuing evacuation orders for communities along the coast for persons to evacuate.

The other area of concern is storm surges.
